title: Owning a Hurtful Comment
situation: In an argument, you said something you know was below the belt. You regret it, but things are still raw.
question: How do you apologize?

choices.label: Wait for them to calm down and act normal around you first.
choices.outcome: They may interpret your silence as not caring about the impact.
choices.insight: When you’re the one who caused harm, waiting for the other person to move first can deepen the hurt.

choices.label: Say, “I’m sorry I said that. It was unfair and I can see how much it hurt you. I’m working on not going there when I’m angry.”
choices.outcome: You name what you did, acknowledge impact, and gesture toward future change.
choices.insight: Good apologies describe the hurtful behavior, not just the feeling of regret.

choices.label: Say, “I’m sorry, but you made me angry,” and focus on what they did first.
choices.outcome: They may feel the apology is conditional and not really about your actions.
choices.insight: Adding a ‘but’ often erases everything that came before it in an apology.
